config.question: What drove the American public toward isolationism in the 1930s?

choices.content: Political instability forced the Americans to set their own house right.
The United States had become too weak to have a say in international affairs.
The Great Depression made foreign policy seem unimportant to many Americans.
A wave of anti-American sentiment kept the United States out of European affairs.

answer_2.response: Consider This: The retreat from an active world policy in the 1920s turned into a headlong flight into isolationism in the 1930s. The America First Committee protested the drift toward war. Such diverse individuals as aviator-hero Charles Lindbergh, conservative Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, socialist leader Norman Thomas, and liberal educator Robert M. Hutchins condemned FDR for involving the United States in a foreign conflict. See L.O. 27.1 Isolationism.
